Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Physics Methods and Algorithmic Applications in Graphical Games and Combinatorial Optimization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The statistical physics field is devoted to the macroscopic properties of matter using a variety of prob-abilistic, statistical and combinatorial tools. Recently, however, it became apparent that some of the tools and observations originating from statistical physics, have applications far beyond their intended scope and are found useful in a variety of fields outside of statistical physics, such as coding theory, information theory,statistical inference in Markov Random Field, and more recently in several core areas of operations research,such as combinatorial optimization and game theory. Specifically, it was discovered, partially in PI's prior work,that the so-called correlation decay (long-range independence) property studied in great depth in statistical physics, has far reaching applications for the design and analysis of algorithms. The goal of the present proposal is to develop this promising approach in a systematic way. Specifically, the PI intends to focus on designing fast (polynomial time) algorithms in the following three challenging algorithmic areas: a) computing pure and mixed Nash equilibrium in graphical games; b) designing deterministic approximation algorithms for counting the number of feasible solutions of an integer programming problem and the problem of computing a volume of a polytope; and c) combinatorial optimization/integer programming problems with stochastic objectives.
This is an exciting new research agenda, which has not been pursued in the operation research field before. The research will lead to new algorithmic design tools and strengthen a newly emerging connections between the fields of algorithms, combinatorial optimization, game theory on the one hand, and statistical physics on the other hand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The statistical physics field is devoted to studying the macroscopic properties of matter using a variety of probabilistic,statistical and combinatorial tools. Some of the key questions include understanding the macroscopic propertiesin equilibrium and the periodicity structures, presence of the long-range order, phase transitions andco-existence of phases, etc. Recently, however, it became apparent that some of the tools and conceptsoriginating from the statistical physics, have applications far beyond their intended scope and are found useful ina variety of fields outside of statistical physics, such as coding theory, information theory, statistical inferencein Markov Random Field, and more recently in several core areas of operations research, such as combinatorialoptimization and game theory.


The goal of the present proposal was to developthis promising approach in a systematic way. Specifically, the work focused on developing applications of the so-called correlation decay property,originating in statistical physics in the context of uniqueness of Gibbs measures and co-existence of phases,to the questions of designing algorithms for optimization and inference problems. The work supported by this grant achieved this goal in several directions.In particular, in a joint work with David Goldberg and Theophane Weber, the correlation decay property was used to design nearly optimal decentralized (local) algorithmsfor optimization problems on networks with stochastic objectives. In particular, such an algorithm was developed for the problem of finding a largest weighted independent subset of an arbitrary sparse graph with random weights. It is notable that the deterministic counterpart of this problem is hard to approximate, unless P=NP. Yet stochastic version is tractable thanks to the correlation decay property. The correlationdecay property was used in a joint work with Dmitriy Katz to develop a deterministic approximationalgorithm for the problem of counting proper colorings of a sparse graph,and further to establish the so-called strong spatial mixing problem for the proper colorings of a graph (joint work with Sidhant Misra).The correlation decay property was also instrumental in my joint work with Kavita Ramanan in studying a linear programming relaxation of the independent set problemdefined on a regular tree. The underlying probability measure corresponding to the volume of the independent set polytop was proved to satisfy the correlationdecay property. This result is promising for designing a deterministic approximation algorithm for computing the volume of a polytop which is one of the majoropen problems in the area of approximation algorithms.


Next, in the joint work with Mohsen Bayati and Prasad Tetali a very challenging open problem was tackled regarding the existence of scaling limits forseveral combinatorial optimization problems in sparse random graphs. The problem was stated in several places and it was one of David Aldous' 6 open problemsin the area of applied probability published in 2000. Our approach was based on the so-called interpolation method originating in the statistical physicsliterature, but thanks to our work, a simpler combinatorial version of it was developed.
